Package com.augursystems.armi

Class HostPort

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.augursystems.armi.HostPort
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Externalizable, java.io.Serializable
    public final class HostPort
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Externalizable
    This encapsulates a host (InetAddress) and port number (int). This implementation should work for IPv6 also (where the IP address is wrapped by brackets), although this has not been tested yet.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor Description
      HostPort()
      Creates a new instance of HostPort containing the local host and the default ARMI port.

      • HostPort

        public HostPort​(java.lang.String hostColonPort)
         throws java.net.UnknownHostException
        Note: The parsing of IPv6 has not been tested yet.
        Parameters:
        hostColonPort - Either "#.#.#.#:#" for IPv4, or "[#:#:#:#:#:#:#:#:#:#:#:#:#:#:#:#]:#" for IPv6; in both formats, the last digit is the port number. If the port is missing (or no colon), then the port is set to zero.
        Throws:
        java.net.UnknownHostException

      • parse

        public static HostPort[] parse​(java.lang.String src)
                        throws java.net.UnknownHostException
        Parses a string of the form "[host1]:[port1], [host2]:[port2], ..." into an IPv4 HostPort[]; the delimeter is any combination of comma and/or space characters; a colon separates each host and port.
        Returns:
        A HostPort[] containing the successfully parsed data; null if it looks like there was no data
        Throws:
        java.net.UnknownHostException - if there is any problem parsing the string, including unknown hosts, bad format, bad port number, etc.
